"'''Economic vulnerability index'''" is one of the criteria used by the [[United Nations]] Committee for Development Policy,<ref>[https://www.un.org/esa/policy/devplan/index.html UN Development Plan]</ref> an advisory body to the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] <ref>[https://www.un.org/ecosoc/ UNECOSOC]</ref> in the identification of Least Developed Countries.<ref>[https://www.un.org/esa/policy/devplan/profile/index.html UN Development Plan index]</ref>
The Economic Vulnerability Index is a composition of the following eight indicators<ref>[https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/policy/cdp/ldc/ldc_criteria.shtml UNDESA : LDC Criteria]</ref>: 1) [[population]] size, 2) remoteness, 3) merchandise [[export]] concentration, 4) share of [[agriculture]], [[forestry]] and [[Fishery|fisheries]] in [[gross domestic product]], 5) [[homelessness]] owing to [[natural disaster]]s, 6) instability of agricultural production, and 7) instability of exports of goods and services, 8) the share of population living in low elevated coastal zone.
The other criteria used to classify countries as least developed are: [[Gross national income]] per capita and the Human Asset Index.<ref>[https://www.un.org/esa/policy/devplan/profile/criteria.html]</ref> In addition, only low-income countries with population smaller than 75 million inhabitants can be considered for inclusion in the category.
Retrospective series have been also calculated for 1990â2011.<ref>[http://www.ferdi.fr/en/node/899 Ferdi]</ref>

{{refimprove|date=April 2010}} [[File:IMages Are Hopefully in Your head since 1982 shirt.jpg|thumb|A T-shirt in Kyoto in 2008. English text has been added for fashion purposes, but the text does not have a comprehensible meaning in English.]] [[File:Toyota RAV4 engrish.jpg|thumb|An example of the Japanese use of English for aesthetic and marketing purposes on a Toyota car spare wheel.]] [[File:Extra Dope Wear Select Shop Ill Store Kyoto.jpg|thumb|A shop front in Kyoto.]] [[File:Engrish Example.jpg|thumb|An Authorized Personnel Only sign at Higashi Hongan-ji Temple in Kyoto, Japan]] '''Engrish''' is a slang term for the misuse or [[Corruption (linguistics)|corruption]] of the [[English language]] by native speakers of [[Asian language]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ziemba|first=Christine N.|title=Translate at your own risk|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/dec/05/entertainment/ca-engrish5|accessdate=13 June 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=December 5, 2004}}</ref> The term itself relates to [[Japanese speakers learning r and l|Japanese speakers' tendency]] to inadvertently substitute the English phonemes "R" and "L" for one another, a process known as [[Lallation]], because, unlike English, the [[Japanese language]] has only one [[liquid consonant]] ([[Romanization of Japanese|traditionally romanized]] with "R"). The related term "[[wasei-eigo]]" refers to [[pseudo-anglicism]]s that have entered into everyday Japanese.
While the term may refer to spoken English, it is more often used to describe written English. In Japan, it is common to add English text to items for decorative and fashion purposes. Such text is often added to create a cosmopolitan feeling rather than to be read by native English speakers, and so may often be meaningless or grammatically incorrect.
Engrish can be found in many places, including signs, menus, and advertisements. Terms such as ''Japanglish'', ''Japlish'' or ''Janglish'' for Japan, ''[[Konglish]]'' for Korea, and ''[[Chinglish]]'' for China are more specific terms for Engrish.{{Citation needed|date=August 2014}}
==Roots of the phenomenon== There are two contributing factors to Japanese Engrish. Firstly, the two languages have significantly different grammar: [[Japanese language#Sentence structure|Japanese word order]], the frequent omission of [[subject (grammar)|subjects]] in Japanese, the absence of [[article (grammar)|articles]], a near-complete absence of consecutive [[consonant]]s, and [[Japanese speakers learning r and l|difficulties in distinguishing /l/ and /r/]], or /Î¸/ and /s/ sounds, all contribute to substantial problems using Standard English effectively.<ref name="Dougill1">{{cite journal|last=Dougill|first=John|title=Japan and English as an alien language|journal=[[English Today]]|year=2008|volume=24|issue=1|pages=18â22|url=http://student.pfmb.uni-mb.si/~mhjurisic/John%20Dougill.pdf|doi=10.1017/S0266078408000059}}</ref> Indeed, Japanese have tended to score comparatively poorly on international tests of English.<ref name="Kowner1">{{cite journal|last=Kowner |first=Rotem |authorlink=Rotem Kowner |title=Japanese Miscommunication with Foreigners: In Search for Valid Accounts and Effective Remedies |journal=Jahrbuch des Deutschen Instituts fÃ¼r Japanstudien |year=2003 |volume=15 |pages=117â151 |url=http://east-asia.haifa.ac.il/staff/kovner/(16)Kowner2003b.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801044152/http://east-asia.haifa.ac.il/staff/kovner/(16)Kowner2003b.pdf |archivedate=2014-08-01 |df= }}</ref>
Secondly, English is frequently used in Japan for aesthetic rather than functional purposes;<ref name="Ikeshima1">{{cite journal|last=Ikeshima|first=Jayne Hildebrand|title=Some perspectives on the phenomenon of "Engrish"|journal=Keio Journal of International Studies|date=July 2005|volume=15|pages=185â198|url=http://www.u-keiai.ac.jp/issn/menu/ronbun/no15/u050708_ikeshima.pdf}}</ref> i.e., for Japanese consumption, not for English speakers ''per se'', as a way of appearing "smart, sophisticated and modern", in much the same way as Japanese and similar writing scripts are used in Western fashion.<ref name="Dougill2">{{cite journal|last=Dougill|first=John|title=English as a decorative language|journal=English Today|year=1987|volume=3|issue=4|pages=33â35|doi=10.1017/S0266078400003126}}</ref> Indeed, it is claimed that in such decorative English "there is often no attempt to try to get it right, nor do the vast majority of the Japanese population ever attempt to read the English design element in question. There is therefore less emphasis on [[spell checker|checking spelling]] and grammatical accuracy."<ref name="Melin1">{{cite journal|last=Melin|first=Tracy|author2=Rey, Nina|title=Emphasizing Foreign Language Use to International Marketing Students: A Situational Exercise That Mimics Real-World Challenges|journal=Global Business Languages|year=2005|volume=10|pages=13â25|url=https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1121&context=gbl}}</ref>
== Other suggested roots == {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} English is taught in Japanese schools with an emphasis on writing and grammar over speaking. The written word is taught using [[Romaji]] (Latin script); however, the correct pronunciation of the Romaji letters is not taught. The spoken word is taught using [[Katakana]] script. Katakana is a [[syllabary]] like [[Hiragana]] but is used specifically (inter alia) â analogously to italics in the Latin script â to denote foreign words (not just English, but also French, German etc.). Katakana script is used in daily life for many foreign words used with Japanese ("[[Gairaigo]]").
The limitations of the Katakana script mean that R and L sounds are not differentiated; and similarly the sounds F and H are expressed by only one character. Furthermore, as Katakana is made up of syllables, not individual letters, there are usually included vowels that should be ignored in a Katakana English word, but are frequently pronounced. Conversely, [[Hard and soft G|soft letters]] are ignored. For example, the English word "start" used when referring to a race, is written in Katakana as ã¹ã¿ã¼ã (su-tÄ-to). The restricted nature of the Katakana set of syllables is what causes the Engrish pronunciation. The answer to this is to teach spoken English using the Latin alphabet. Many Japanese people know how to write English very well, but are not confident speakers due to this issue. It is not uncommon to receive a perfectly well-composed e-mail in English from a Japanese person, only to find that in person they will not attempt to speak English, preferring to apologise that they cannot speak, only write English.
==In popular culture== Instances of Engrish due to poor translation were frequently found in many early video games produced in Japan, often due to the creators not having enough (or not wanting to spend enough) money for proper translations.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} One well-known example of Engrish in pop culture is the translation of the video game ''[[Zero Wing]]'' which gave birth to the phenomenon [[All your base are belong to us]], which also became an [[Internet meme]]. This phenomenon is parodied in ''[[Mario & Luigi: Superstar Saga]]'',{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} in which the character [[Fawful]] speaks Engrish. In the Japanese version of ''[[Mario & Luigi: Bowser's Inside Story]]'' (in which Fawful also appears as the main antagonist), in the same subseries, the character Broque Monsieur also speaks Engrish.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Engrish has been featured occasionally in the [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] cartoon ''[[South Park]]'', such as the song "Let's Fighting Love", used in the episode "[[Good Times with Weapons]]", which parodies the poorly translated opening theme sequences sometimes shown in [[anime]], and in Parker and Stone's feature length ''[[Team America: World Police]]'' where the North Korean leader [[Kim Jong Il]] is depicted singing the song "I'm so Ronery".<ref name="WP South Park">{{cite news|last=Stuever|first=Hank|title=Puppet Government 'South Park' Creators' Left Jab at Jingoism May Backfire|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A34313-2004Oct15.html|accessdate=16 September 2011|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=October 15, 2004|quote=The North Korean dictator speaks in the voice of "South Park's" Eric Cartman, ... only with an Engrish accent. "I'm so ronery," Kim confesses in a pitiful ballad to himself, which explains his evil-doing -- he just needs to be ruvved.}}</ref>
The British fashion brand [[Superdry]], in a reverse parody of the phenomenon, has established a style of placing meaningless Japanese text such as 'Sunglasses company' and 'membership certificate' on clothing sold in Britain. The company explained to a Japanese television crew that most translations were done using simple automatic translation programs such as [[Yahoo! Babel Fish|Babelfish]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Superdry: Popular UK Fashion Brand Uses Gibberish Japanese|url=http://www.japanprobe.com/2011/10/16/superdry-popular-uk-fashion-brand-uses-gibberish-japanese/|website=Japan Probe|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Superdry|url=http://www.unmissablejapan.com/etcetera/superdry|website=Unmissable Japan|accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref>
''[[Monty Python's Flying Circus]]'' featured a parody of the drama series ''[[Elizabeth R]]'', where they portrayed the cast riding motor-scooters and speaking Engrish, thus changing the title to "Erizabeth L".
In the 1983 film ''[[A Christmas Story]]'', the Parker family goes to a Chinese restaurant for their Christmas dinner, and are serenaded by the waitstaff with Engrish Christmas carols, such as "[[Deck the Halls|Deck the harrs]] wis boughs of horry, fa ra ra ra ra ra ra ra ra" and "[[Jingle Bells|Jingre berrs]], jingre berrs, jingre arr the way, oh what fun it is to ride in one-horse open sreigh!"<ref>StarWalker13 (April 26, 2009). {{YouTube | xTq20prt0K8 | "A Christmas Story Chinese Restaurant Scene"}}</ref>
==See also== * [[All your base are belong to us]] * [[Broken English]] * [[Japanese Pidgin English]] * [[Non-native pronunciations of English]] * [[Perception of English /r/ and /l/ by Japanese speakers]] * [[Wasei-eigo]] ** [[List of wasei-eigo]] {{div col end}}

{{Distinguish|text = the [[European Community Humanitarian Aid Office]], currently named Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations}} [[File:Alfonso XIII, de Kaulak.jpg|thumb|King Alfonso XIII in 1915]] The '''European War Office''' ({{lang-es|Oficina de la Guerra Europea}} or ''Oficina Pro Cautivos'') was a humanitarian office created by [[King Alfonso XIII of Spain]] to help the victims of the [[First world war|First World War]] no matter which side they fought on or whether they were civilians or military. This office depended directly from the [[Private Secretary]] of the King and had its headquarters in the [[Royal Palace of Madrid]].
One of the most importants achieves that the King made was to get a compromise from both sides of the conflicts to stop sinking of more [[Hospital ship|hospital-ships]]. As a result, Spanish naval observers sailed in the hospital-ships of various countries to make sure that the ships were being used for that purpose, rather than for military expeditions.The king also cooperated in the creation of a special signal code for hospital-ships.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Alfonso XIII and Spainâs Humanitarian Work|last=Gracia Rivas|first=Manuel|publisher=Revista EspaÃ±ola de Defensa|year=2014|isbn=|location=Madrid|pages=60}}</ref>
==Spanish neutrality== {{Main|Spain during World War I}} During the World War I, [[Spain]] remained neutral because of many reason, one of the most important for the King was his family ties (His wife was British and his mother Austrian, amongst other family relationships). But this fact did not prevent the King from getting involved in the war, creating the European War Office.
On August 7, 1914, it was published in [[Gazeta de Madrid|Madrid's Gazette]] a Royal Decree signed by both King Alfonso and [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] [[Eduardo Dato]] declaring the country neutral and saying that the government had the Â«duty to order the strictest neutrality to Spanish subjects in accordance with the laws in force and the principles of public international lawÂ».
For the [[Government of Spain|Government]], there was no reason to enter in the conflict and there was no enough resources to do so,<ref>{{Cite book|title=A century of Spain: politics and society|last=JuliÃ¡|first=Santos|publisher=Marcial Pons|year=1999|isbn=84-9537903-1|location=Madrid|pages=40}}</ref> something that the political and economic class was agreed with.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Liberal Spain (1868-1917)|last=SuÃ¡rez Cortina|first=Manuel|publisher=|year=2006|isbn=84-9756-415-4|location=Madrid|pages=185}}</ref> The King also agreed despite of having commented with the French ambassador his wish of entering in the conflict in the [[Allies of World War I|allies side]] in exchange of a Â«some tangible satisfactionÂ» âprobably referring to [[Tangier]]â.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Alfonso XIII. The controversial king.|last=Tusell|first=Javier|last2=GarcÃ­a Queipo de Llano|first2=Genoveva|publisher=Taurus|year=2002|isbn=84-306-0449-9|location=Madrid|pages=284; 287-288}}</ref>
Another important reason for Spanish neutrality was the precariousness of its [[Spanish Armed Forces|armed forces]]. Spain was involved in numerous conflicts in the north of Africa because of its [[Spanish protectorate in Morocco|protectorate of Morocco]]. This situation supposed an outdated [[Spanish Army|Army]], with bad supplies and because of the large number of [[Officer (armed forces)|officers]], most of the budget went to pay their salaries. The [[Spanish Navy|Navy]]'s reputation was very damaged because of the defeat in the [[Spanish-American War of 1898|American-Spanish War of 1898]] and it wasn't until a decade later when the government started again to invest in new warships, causing that the navy wasn't ready to enter into a war.
To all this we have to add the social unrest because of the growing of the labor movement and the appearance of left-wing republican parties that could cause a major conflict like happenned in the [[Russian Revolution]] if the conflict would be unfavorable to Spain.
==The Office== [[File:1918-06-22, Heraldo de Madrid, JuliÃ¡n JuderÃ­as.jpg|thumb|JuliÃ¡n JuderÃ­as in 1918]] The Office, with its headquarters in the Royal Palace, started around 1914 with just six staff. The publication in a french newspaper, Le Petit Girondais, a thank you letter provoked an avalanche of letters from many europeans asking for help. This forced the King to enlarge the office to 48 staff members, all of them speaking several languages and many volunteers. Among them was the historian and translator [[JuliÃ¡n JuderÃ­as]] whom spoke 15 languages.
The office worked in coordination with the [[Red Cross]] and was structurated in several sections:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://encyclopedia.1914-1918-online.net/article/alfonso_xiii_king_of_spain|title=Alfonso XIII, King of Spain {{!}} International Encyclopedia of the First World War (WW1)|access-date=2018-11-11}}</ref> * Missing People. *Information and Correspondence in Occupied Territories. *Prisoners. *Repatriations of Soldiers Severely Wounded or Sick. *Repatriations of Civilians. *Internment Service in Switzerland. *Pardons. *Commutations of Sentences. *Remittance of Funds to Individuals and Families in Occupied Territories. *Reports on Inspection Visits by Spanish Delegates.
The Office received more than 200,000 letters â140,000 of them from relatives of soldiersâ all of whom were answered thanks to what Juan JosÃ© Alonso MartÃ­n, director of the Palace General Archives, has described as Â«a primitive computing system.Â»<ref name=ElPaÃ­s>{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/11/08/inenglish/1541680126_698719.html|title=A king with a mission: the humanitarian deeds of Alfonso XIII during the Great War|last=Olaya|first=Vicente G.|date=2018-11-09|work=El PaÃ­s|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en|issn=1134-6582}}</ref>
The efforts of the King wasn't only to find people's relatives but to stop some executions. It's calculated that around a hundred people were saved from execution thanks to this office âincluding French and German soldiersâ. The King even tried to save [[Tsar Nicholas II of Russia]] and his family with no success.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/why-no-nation-would-rescue-nicholas-ii-and-his-family-from-revolutionary-russia/2018/08/02/bf5fcf0e-6a77-11e8-bea7-c8eb28bc52b1_story.html|title=Review {{!}} Why no nation would rescue Nicholas II and his family from revolutionary Russia|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespanol.com/cultura/historia/20181109/espana-gran-guerra-mediador-alfonso-xiii-cataluna/351715887_0.html|title=EspaÃ±a en la Gran Guerra: del mediador Alfonso XIII a las llamas en CataluÃ±a|work=El EspaÃ±ol|access-date=2018-11-11|language=es}}</ref> The Palace General Archives have more than 90 documents sent to [[St. Petersburg]] that proves the efforts to liberate or visit the Tsar âthe office's staff visited more than 4,000 prisoners over all Europeâ but the [[Romanovs]] were already dead by when the rescue operation started. Even this, the King was not sure of the fate of the [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Tsarina]] and her children so he and his office continued trying it.<ref name=ElPaÃ­s/>
There is also evidence that his efforts were instrumental in lifting the siege on [[Belgium]] so that food from the [[United States]] could reach its nine million inhabitants.
=== Recognition === The diplomats involved in the operation received the [[Medal of French Gratitude|Reconnaissance FranÃ§aise medal]], the women received the Red Cross medal and the rest of the staff received the [[Order of Isabella the Catholic|Order of Isabel the Catholic Queen]].
King Alfonso himself was thanked by the people of Belgium and [[Italy]] in 1923.<ref name="ElPaÃ­s" /> He was also greatly admired around the world. A young English girl even wrote this prayer which appeared in a newspaper: Â«''And God bless Father and Mother, and Nurse, and send Father back soon from his horrid prison in Germany. And God bless specially the dear King of Spain who found out about Father. Amen.Â»''<ref>{{Cite book|title=Alfonso XIII and the War: The Mirror of Neutrals|last=EspinÃ³s MoltÃ³|first=VÃ­ctor|publisher=|year=1918|isbn=8473350057|location=|pages=59}}</ref>
In 1917, King Alfonso was nominated for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]], but it was given to the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]]. He was nominated again in 1933, when he was already in exile. In honor of its royal visitor, Le Meurice Hotel has a room with his name, Suite Royale Alphonse XIII, where the very famous Spanish painter [[Salvador DalÃ­]] spent one month every year for thirty years.
==Featured cases== * French actor and singer [[Maurice Chevalier]] was taken prisoner in Germany and it was thank to the secret intervention of King Alfonso that he was released.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musiqueenligne.com/artist_bio.php?lg=en&id=2250|title=Biography : Maurice CHEVALIER|last=comkoenig|website=www.musiqueenligne.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-11}}</ref> * Russian ballet dancer [[Vaslav Nijinsky]] was arrested in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] and was release thanks to the intervention, among other international leaders, of King Alfonso.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livingwithschizophreniauk.org/nijinsky/|title=Nijinsky - Living With Schizophrenia|work=Living With Schizophrenia|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en-GB}}</ref> * In the Royal Palace's archive exists a complaint about the bad situation of future French president [[Charles de Gaulle|Charles De Gaulle]] made by the Spanish inspectors sent by the King to a war camp.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.es/cultura/abci-alfonso-xiii-convirtio-palacio-real-oficina-esperanza-guerra-mundial-201702120111_noticia.html|title=Alfonso XIII, el Rey que convirtiÃ³ el Palacio Real en una oficina de la esperanza en la I Guerra Mundial|work=abc|access-date=2018-11-11|language=es-ES}}</ref> * With only 8-years-old, a french girl named Sylviane Sartor sent a letter to the King asking him to find her uncle that was a war prisoner and saying that that would made her mother stop crying. She said the following: Â«''Your Majesty, Mother is crying all the time because her brother has been taken prisoner. She has just received a letter that says he will die of hunger. Your Majesty, if you could send him to Switzerlandâ¦ because Mother is certainly going to make herself ill. Your Majesty, I thank you in advance. Your servant, Sylviane''Â». The King answered back that letter by asking for more information: Â«''Dear Miss, I will do my best to stop your mother from crying. So be so good as to send me exact news of your uncle so that I can take the matter further. Alfonso XIII, King.''Â» The prisioner was Achille Delmonte, found in a camp in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]] and sent back to [[Switzerland]] with his family.<ref name=ElPaÃ­s/> *The French prime minister asked the King to try to get the repatriation of 20,000 French civilians that the war had surprised in the enemy zone, and that they had been deported to internment camps. Alfonso XIII achieved his liberation in a few months, and France considered him a war hero ever since.<ref name=Alcelay>{{Cite book|title=Alfonso XIII, el hÃ©roe de guerra olvidado|last=Alcelay|first=Carlos|publisher=mujerhoy.com|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> *The efforts of the office were unsuccessful in the search for John Kipling, the only son of the Nobel Prize for literature [[Rudyard Kipling]]. His remains were not found and identified until 1922.<ref name=Alcelay/>
==Public exhibition== Nowadays, all these letters and documents from the European War Office are property of the [[Royal Palace of Madrid]] archives and it forms part of a public exhibition called ''Letters to the King. The humanitarian activities of Alfonso XIII during the Great War'' that will be open between November 8, 2018 and March 3, 2019. It can be visited in the Genoa Rooms of the Royal Palace of Madrid.
==See also== * [[World War I]] * [[Diplomacy]]
==External links== * [https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/11/06/album/1541507868_653298.html#foto_gal_1 Some pictures of the public exhibition]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox organization | name = Financial Stability Board | named_after = | image = Fsb-logo.svg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | abbreviation = FSB | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|2009|04}} | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Swiss association|Verein]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]] | location = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | sec_gen = | leader_title = Chairman | leader_name = [[Mark Carney]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/regulators-examine-financial-stability-risks-to-climate-change-oil-exposure-1459444688|title=Regulators Examine Financial Risks of Climate Change|first=Gabriele | last=Steinhauser|date=31 March 2016|work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> | leader_title2 = Secretary General | leader_name2 = Dietrich Domanski | board_of_directors = | key_people = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = [[Bank for International Settlements]], [[G20]] | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | staff = 33 | staff_year = 2017 | mission = | website = {{URL|fsb.org}} | formerly = [[Financial Stability Forum]] (FSF) }}
The '''Financial Stability Board''' ('''FSB''') is an international body that monitors and makes recommendations about the [[global financial system]]. It was established after the [[2009 G20 London summit|G20 London summit]] in April 2009 as a successor to the [[Financial Stability Forum]] (FSF). The Board includes all [[G20 major economies]], FSF members, and the [[European Commission]]. Hosted and funded by the [[Bank for International Settlements]], the board is based in [[Basel, Switzerland|Basel]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsb.org/contact/|title=Contact|publisher=}}</ref>
== History == ===Financial Stability Forum === {{Main|Financial Stability Forum}}
The FSB's predecessor organization, the Financial Stability Forum (FSF), had emerged from a group of [[finance ministry|finance ministries]], [[central bank]]ers, and international financial bodies, which had been founded in 1999 to promote international financial stability by the finance ministers and central bank governors of [[G7]] countries.<ref name="Founding">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Genesis of the FSF | url = http://www.fsforum.org/about/genesis_of_the_fsf.html| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| archive-date = 14 June 2008| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080614141837/http://www.fsforum.org/about/genesis_of_the_fsf.html | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> The FSF facilitated discussion and cooperation on supervision and surveillance of financial institutions, transactions, and events. FSF was managed by a small secretariat housed at the [[Bank for International Settlements]] in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]].<ref name="FSF home">{{cite web | title = Home/News| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| date = | url = http://www.fsforum.org| archive-date = 12 May 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090512222115/http://www.fsforum.org/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> The FSF membership included about a dozen nations who participate through their central banks, financial ministries and departments, and securities regulators, including: the [[United States]], [[Japan]], [[Germany]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]], the [[Netherlands]] and several other industrialized economies as well as several international economic organizations.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Who we are | url = http://www.fsforum.org/about/who_we_are.html| work = | publisher = Financial Stability Forum| archive-date = 14 June 2008| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080614141842/http://www.fsforum.org/about/who_we_are.html| format = | doi = | accessdate = 30 April 2016 }}</ref> At the G20 summit on 15 November 2008, it was agreed that the membership of the FSF will be expanded to include emerging economies, such as China. The [[2009 G20 London summit]] decided to establish a successor to the FSF, the Financial Stability Board (FSB) to include members of the G20 who had not been FSF members.<ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Financial Stability Forum decides to broaden its membership |work= |publisher=Financial Stability Forum |date=12 March 2009 |url=http://www.fsforum.org/press/pr_090312b.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411064057/http://www.fsforum.org/press/pr_090312b.pdf |archive-date=11 April 2009 |format= |doi= |accessdate=30 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
===Founding === The Financial Stability Forum met in [[Rome]] on 28â29 March 2008 in connection with the [[Bank for International Settlements]]. Members discussed current challenges in financial markets, and various policy options to address them from this point forward.<ref name="BIS 0308">{{cite web|url= http://www.bis.org/press/p080329.htm |title=Press release: Financial Stability Forum meets in Rome|publisher=}}</ref> At this meeting, the FSF discussed a report to be delivered to [[G7]] Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors in April 2008. The report identifies key weaknesses underlying current financial turmoil, and recommends actions to improve market and institutional resilience. The FSF discussed work underway at the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] with regard to [[sovereign wealth fund]]s. The International Monetary Fund is working closely with sovereign wealth funds to identify a set of voluntary best practice guidelines, and is focusing on the governance, institutional arrangements and transparency of sovereign wealth funds.<ref name="BIS 0308"/> On 12 April 2008, the FSF delivered a report to the G7 Finance Ministers detailing its recommendations:<ref name="FSFReport">{{cite book|title=Report of the Financial Stability Forum on Enhancing Market and Institutional Resilience|date=7 April 2008|publisher=Financial Stability Forum|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/r_0804.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bis.org/press/p080412.htm|title=Press release: Financial Stability Forum Recommends Actions to Enhance Market and Institutional Resilience|publisher=}}</ref> * Strengthen prudential oversight of capital, liquidity, and risk management * Enhance transparency and valuation * Change the role and uses of [[credit rating]]s * Strengthen the authorities' responsiveness to risks * Make robust arrangements for dealing with stress in the financial system
=== 2012 reforms === The High-Level Panel on the Governance of the FSB was an independent initiative coordinated by [[Domenico Lombardi]] of the [[Brookings Institution]] and funded by the [[The Connect U.S. Fund|Connect U.S. Fund]]. It assembled a high-level panel of experts, including [[Uganda]]'s former [[Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (Uganda)|Finance Minister]] and [[Governor of the Bank of Uganda|Central Bank Governor]] of Uganda [[Ezra Suruma]], former [[Prime Minister of Kyrgyzstan|Prime Minister]] of [[Kyrgyzstan]] [[Djoomart Otorbaev]], former [[Minister of Finance and Public Credit of Colombia|Finance Minister]] of [[Colombia]] [[JosÃ© Antonio Ocampo]], and [[Jacques Mistral]], a former member of [[France]]'s Council of Economic Analysis.<ref name="newrules">{{cite web|title=What We Do: High-Level Panel on the Governance of the Financial Stability Board|url=http://www.new-rules.org/what-we-do/fsb-unlocking-the-black-box/hlp-on-fsb-governance|website=New Rules for Global Finance|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> Lombardi published the panel's final report in September 2011 as a Brookings Issue Paper, concluding that the FSB's governance had not evolved as quickly as its prominence. It made several recommendations:<ref name="brookings">{{cite book|author1=Domenico Lombardi|authorlink1=Domenico Lombardi|title=The Governance of the Financial Stability Board|date=September 2011|publisher=Brookings Institution|location=Washington, DC|url=https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/FSB_Issues_Paper_Lombardi.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
At the [[2011 G20 Cannes summit]], the G20 called for a strengthening of the FSB's capacity resources and governance by establishing the FSB "on an enduring organizational basis".<ref name="history">{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.fsb.org/about/history/|website=Financial Stability Board|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> In its 2012 report to the [[2012 G20 Los Cabos summit|G20 Los Cabos summit]], the FSB set out concrete steps to strengthen the organization's capacity, resources, and governance as well as establish it on an enduring organizational footing. The G20 endorsed the FSB's restated and amended charter.<ref>{{cite book|title=Report to the G20 Los Cabos Summit on Strengthening FSB Capacity, Resources and Governance|date=12 June 2012|publisher=Financial Stability Board|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/r_120619c.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> In January 2013, the FSB became a separate legal entity in the form of an association or "Verein" under Swiss law, when its Articles of Association were adopted by the FSB Plenary.<ref name="ar4">{{cite book|author1=Financial Stability Board|title=4th Annual Report|date=December 2017|publisher=Financial Stability Board|location=Basel|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/P160118.pdf}}</ref>
The FSB is hosted and funded by the Bank for International Settlements under a five-year agreement executed between the two in January 2013. The bank bears the majority of the FSB's operating expenses, and the FSB does not have any assets, liabilities, or revenue.<ref name="ar4"/>
=== 2016 reforms===
In late July 2016, after the world markets had faced a number of crises, including terrorism and the UK's [[Brexit|decision to leave]] the [[European Union]], Carney sent a letter to Finance Ministers attending the G20 Summit and to Central Bank Governors outlining the reforms the FSB had made<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theasianbanker.com/press-releases/fsb-chair-updates-g20-finance-ministers-and-central-bank-governors-on-progress-in-advancing-the-fsb%E2%80%99s-2016-priorities |title=FSB Chair updates G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors on progress in advancing the FSBâs 2016 priorities |author= |date=24 July 2016 |website=The Asian Banker |access-date=25 July 2016 |quote=The letter outlines the progress the FSB is making in advancing its priorities for 2016}}</ref> indicating that the global economy and financial system had "continued to function effectively" and had "weathered" the "spikes in uncertainty and risk aversion", confirming that "this resilience in the face of stress demonstrates the enduring benefits of G20 post-crisis reforms". He emphasized the value of specific reforms that had been implemented by the Financial Stability Board stating that these had "dampened aftershocks from [global financial crises] rather than amplifying them". He expressed confidence in the FSB's strategies, stating that "resilience in the face of stress demonstrates the enduring benefits of G20 post-crisis reforms".<ref>{{cite news |last=Szu |first=Ping Chan |date=24 July 2016 |title=G20: Chancellor eyes clarity on Brexit deal 'later this year' as vote raises global risks |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/07/24/g20-chancellor-eyes-clarity-on-brexit-deal-later-this-year-as-vo |work=The Telegraph |location=London, UK |access-date=25 July 2016}}</ref>
The FSB published the pre-G20 summit letter<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fsb.org/2016/07/fsb-chair-updates-g20-finance-ministers-and-central-bank-governors-on-progress-in-advancing-the-fsbs-2016-priorities/ |title=FSB Chair updates G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors on progress in advancing the FSBâs 2016 priorities |author=|date=24 July 2016 |website=FSB |publisher=FSB |access-date=25 July 2016}}</ref> in light of the "two spikes in uncertainty and risk aversion" weathered by the global economy and financial system as of late July 2016, which outlined its priorities for 2016: * Promote a coordinated program of reforms to deliver resilient sources of market-based finance, including addressing structural vulnerabilities associated with [[asset management]] * Develop robust financial market infrastructure, including assessing policies on central counterparty resilience, recovery, and resolvability, and recommending any necessary improvements * Support effective [[Macroprudential regulation|macroprudential]] arrangements by drawing lessons from countries that have applied macroprudential policy frameworks and tools, working in partnership with the [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[Bank for International Settlements]]
In addition to the priorities listed above, the FSB also sought to: * Pursue the full and consistent implementation of post-crisis reforms, while addressing material unintended consequences * Address new and emerging vulnerabilities in the financial system, including those associated with conduct, correspondent banking and climate change * Monitor the potentially systemic implications of [[Financial technology|financial technology]] [[Financial innovation|innovations]], and the systemic risks arising from operational disruptions
In November 2016, the FSB and the board of the Bank for International Settlements agreed to a further five-year extension of the agreement from January 2018 to 2023.<ref name="ar4"/>
== Overview == The FSB represented the G20 leaders' first major international institutional innovation. [[U.S. Treasury]] [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary]] [[Tim Geithner]] has described it as "in effect, a fourth pillar" of the architecture of global economic governance. The FSB has been assigned a number of important tasks, working alongside the International Monetary Fund, [[World Bank]], and the [[World Trade Organization]]. Chairman of the board is the Canadian [[Mark Carney]], [[Governor of the Bank of England|Governor]] of the [[Bank of England]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mark Carney gets chance to reshape Bank of England after departure of deputy governor|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2013/06/14/mark-carney-gets-chance-to-reshape-bank-of-england-as-deputy-governor-departs |accessdate=20 June 2013|work=[[Financial Post]]|date=13 June 2013}}</ref>
Unlike most multilateral financial institutions, the FSB lacks a legal form and any formal power, given that its charter is an informal and nonbinding memorandum of understanding for cooperation adopted by its members.<ref name="brookings"/>
=== Membership === The FSB has 68 member institutions, comprising ministries of finance, central banks, and supervisory and regulatory authorities from 25 jurisdictions as well as 10 international organizations and [[Standards organization|standard-setting bodies]], and 6 Regional Consultative Groups reaching out to 65 other jurisdictions around the world.<ref name="ar4"/><ref name="Members">{{cite web |url=http://www.financialstabilityboard.org/members/links.htm |title=Links to FSB members |publisher=Financial Stability Board |accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref>

=== Chairs ===
As a 2011 [[Brookings Institution]] report noted, there are no set rules for how the FSB chair is selected, reflecting the FSB's newness as well as the "central banking culture of discretion and informality that permeates the institution".<ref name = "brookings"/>
* [[Mario Draghi]] (2009â2011), current [[President of the European Central Bank|President]] of the [[European Central Bank]] and former Governor of the [[Banca d'Italia|Bank of Italy]] * [[Mark Carney]] (2011âpresent), current [[Governor of the Bank of England|Governor]] of the [[Bank of England]] and former [[Governor of the Bank of Canada|Governor]] of the [[Bank of Canada]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Free-to-view}} '''Free-to-air''' ('''FTA''') are [[television]] (TV) and [[radio]] services broadcast in clear ([[Encryption|unencrypted]]) form, allowing any person with the [[FTA Receiver|appropriate receiving equipment]] to receive the signal and view or listen to the content without requiring a [[Pay television|subscription]], other ongoing cost or one-off fee (e.g. [[Pay-per-view]]). In the traditional sense, this is carried on [[Radio|terrestrial radio]] signals and received with an antenna.
FTA also refers to channels and broadcasters providing content for which no subscription is expected, even though they may be delivered to the viewer/listener by another carrier for which a subscription is required, e.g. [[Cable television|cable]], [[satellite television|satellite]] or the [[Internet]]. These carriers may be mandated (or opt) in some geographies to deliver FTA channels even if a premium subscription is not present (providing the necessary equipment is still available), especially where FTA channels are expected to be used for emergency broadcasts, similar to the [[1-1-2|112]] emergency service provided by mobile phone operators and manufacturers.
[[Free-to-view]] (FTV) is, generally, available without [[subscription]] but is digitally encoded and may be restricted geographically.
Free-to-air is often used for [[international broadcasting]], making it something of a video equivalent to [[shortwave radio]]. Most FTA retailers list free to air channel guides and content available in North America for free to air use.
== Funding == Although commonly described as free, the cost of free-to-air services is met through various means: * Tax payer funding * with an enforced levy of a [[television licence|licence fee]] for transmission and production costs (e.g., the [[BBC]]) * with a voluntary donation for local transmission and production costs (e.g., [[PBS]]) * with commercial advertising for transmission and production costs and surplus revenues returned to the government (e.g., [[CBC Television]]/[[TÃ©lÃ©vision de Radio-Canada]] in [[Canada]], [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] in Australia and [[TVNZ]] in New Zealand) * Commercial sponsorship * Consumer products and services where part of the cost goes toward television [[advertising]] and [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsorship]] (in the case of Japanese television broadcasters like [[TV Asahi]] and [[TV Tokyo]] which rely heavily on sponsorship, similar to Philippine broadcasters like [[ABS-CBN]], [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] and [[GMA Network|GMA]])
== Americas ==
=== Brazil === In [[Brazil]] the main FTA satellite is the [[Star One C2]], it holds approximately 30 C-band analog channels, including all major networks like [[Rede Globo]], [[Sistema Brasileiro de TelevisÃ£o|SBT]], [[Rede Record|Record]], [[RedeTV!]], [[Rede Bandeirantes|Band]] and others, and 5 digital [[HDTV]] channels.+itv 1
=== North America === There are a number of competing systems in use. Early adopters used C-band [[satellite dish|dishes]] several feet in diameter to receive analog microwave broadcasts, and later digital microwave broadcasts using the 3.7-4.2 GHz band. Today, although large C-band dishes can still receive some content, the 11.7-12.2 GHz {{Ku band}} is also used. Ku-band signals can be received using smaller dishes, often as small as under a meter in diameter, allowing FTA satellite to be picked up from smaller spaces such as apartment balconies (note, however, that these dishes are not quite as small as those commonly used for commercial services such as Dish Network, DirecTV, Bell ExpressVu, Shaw Direct, etc. Dishes intended for those services may not deliver an adequate signal on Ku-band). The European-developed [[DVB-S]] and [[DVB-S2]] standards are the most commonly used broadcast methods, with analog transmissions almost completely discontinued as of mid-2014.
The most common North American sources for free-to-air DVB [[satellite television]] are: * [[NHK World]] HD on [[Intelsat 9]] (58Â°W) * [[Retro Television Network]], [[TuffTV]] on [[AMC 9]] (83Â°W) * [[Louisiana Public Broadcasting|LPB]] Louisiana PBS channels LPBHD, LPB2, and LPB3 (Create) on [[SES 2]] (89Â°W) * [[NASA TV]] Multi-channel (NASA TV Public-Education, NASA Media, NASA TV UHD) on [[Horizons-1]] (aka Galaxy 13) (127Â°W) * [[Eternal Word Television Network]] on [[Galaxy 17]] (91Â°W) * [[My Family TV]], [[CGTN (TV channel)|CGTN]] on [[Galaxy 3C]] (95Â°W). * [[AMGTV]] and [[BYUtv|BYU Television]] (BYUtv) on [[Galaxy 19]] (97Â°W) * English and foreign language broadcasters [[RT (TV network)]], [[Ebru TV]], [[Islamic Republic of Iran News Network|IRINN]], [[Al Jazeera English]] and more up-linked by [[GlobeCast World TV]] on [[Galaxy 19]] (97Â°W) * Christian broadcasters such as [[The Word Network]], [[Emmanuel TV]], [[Daystar Television Network]], [[JCTV]], [[Trinity Broadcasting Network]], [[The Church Channel]], [[3ABN]], [[The Hope Channel]], [[Amazing Facts]] Television, [[God's Learning Channel]] are broadcast from the [[Galaxy 19]] (97Â°W) satellite for [[Glorystar]] and [[Spiritcast]] Satellite Systems TV. * Peace TV English and Peace TV Urdu language which are global Islamic channels, available on Galaxy 19 (97Â°W) * [[DoD News]] on [[AMC 1]] (103Â°W) * [[Jewish Life Television]] on [[Galaxy 18]] (123Â°W) * [[Montana PBS|Montana Public Broadcasting Service]] and other [[PBS Satellite Service]]s on AMC 21 (125Â°W) * [[Classic Arts Showcase]] on [[Galaxy 17]] (91Â°W) and [[Eternal Word Television Network]] HD on [[Galaxy 15]] (133Â°W) * Football, Basketball, Baseball, Soccer, and Hockey [[wildfeed]]s on various satellites * Infowars and Alex Jones Show broadcasts from Austin, TX and creates free to air 24/7 content on Galaxy 16 99Â°W
Most of these signals are carried by [[United States|US]] satellites. There is little or no free Canadian DVB-S content available to users of medium-size dishes as much of the available Ku-band satellite bandwidth is occupied by [[pay-TV]] operators [[Shaw Direct]] and [[Bell TV]], although larger C-band dishes can pick up some content. FTA signals may be scattered across multiple satellites, requiring a motor or multiple [[Low-noise block downconverter|LNB]]s to receive everything. This differs from Europe, where FTA signals are commonly concentrated on a few specific satellites.
Another difference between North American FTA and FTA in most of the rest of the world is that in North America, very few of the available signals are actually intended for home viewers or other end-users. Instead, they are generally intended for reception by local television stations, cable system headends, or other commercial users. While it is generally thought to be legal for home viewers to view such transmissions as long as they are not encrypted, this means that there are several unique challenges to viewing FTA signals that are not present in other areas of the world. Among these are:
* No schedule information is provided with most of the signals, therefore satellite receivers cannot show a proper [[electronic program guide]] ([[EPG]]). * Because many of these broadcasts are essentially point-to-point transmissions, the originators often do not follow any international standards when setting various identification fields in the data stream. This causes issues with receivers and software designed for use in other parts of the world, as they may assume that if a channel contains the same ID information as another channel, those are duplicate channels. This may be a valid assumption in other parts of the world, but is almost never valid for North American FTA signals. When such an assumption is made, during a "blind scan" the receiver or software will often fail to correctly insert one or more channels into its database, or it may overwrite previously scanned valid channels (including other channels on the same satellite) with invalid information picked up from another, more recently scanned channel. If the end user does not understand what is happening, they may assume that the receiver cannot receive certain channels or that it is defective, yet if the correct data for those channels can be manually entered, those channels may become receivable. This problem can be mitigated if receivers can be set to ignore channels that appear to be duplicates during a "blind scan", except when such channels are on exactly the same satellite and same transponder frequency (as might occur if the user rescans a previously-scanned satellite). * Channels tend to come and go, or change transmission formats, often without any prior notice other than to their intended recipients. This means that a working channel could suddenly disappear without warning, and may need to be rescanned to become receivable again, or it may be gone permanently. * Channels that are currently FTA can become scrambled (encrypted) with no advance warning. A few channels tend to go back and forth between being "in the clear" (unscrambled) to scrambled at various times, but in most cases, once a channel is scrambled it stays scrambled. * Historically, it has appeared that broadcasters are more likely to scramble their signals when they become aware that home viewers and other "unauthorized" viewers are watching their signals. Therefore, those who know what signals are available may sometimes be reluctant to share that information in open forums. While sites exist that attempt to list currently viewable FTA signals, most of them are incomplete or do not contain current information. Such sites typically rely on reports of changes by viewers, and if viewers are reluctant to report new FTA signals for fear they might disappear, it becomes more of a challenge for such sites to maintain up-to-date listings. * What some would consider the most desirable signals, e.g. feeds from broadcast networks, are primarily only available on C-band, which requires a large dish (usually at least 6 feet/1.8 meters in diameter or more, although a few hobbyists have found it possible to receive some C-band signals using smaller dishes and high quality LNB's). Also some of those signals utilize high-bitrate formats that cannot be received by many older receivers, even if those receivers are capable of receiving digital signals, and such signals may require a larger than usual dish for adequate reception. In many areas, local zoning laws and/or homeowner associations forbid the placement of a large dish, therefore such dishes have fallen out of favor since commercial satellite services became widely available. Therefore, very few people have the capability to receive the C-band broadcasts. Another issue is that properly aiming a C-band dish is not something that a typical end-user would know how to do, since it tends to be a somewhat complex procedure (especially when a moveable dish is used with the intention of tracking the visible satellite arc in order to receive multiple satellites), and many of the installers that knew how to set up and correctly aim a C-band dish have exited the business. * While equipment and software is becoming available that allows home users to set up a backend system that can deliver received over-the-air [[ATSC]] signals to several frontend systems (for example, a [[HDHomeRun]], [[VBox Home TV Gateway]] or similar TV tuner, used with [[MythTV]] or [[TVHeadEnd]]), a similar system for receiving FTA signals is considerably more difficult to set up. While PCI/PCIe tuner cards and USB tuners for DVB-S and DVB-S2 are available, there are often issues with drivers, or the cards may simply not be compatible with the backend software in use. Therefore, setting up such a system for FTA satellite reception tends to require considerably more technical knowledge, and a willingness to work through issues, than setting up such a system for receiving terrestrial signals. * Some syndicated programming is being sent as data, similar to the way a video file might be sent over the Internet. This means that the programming is not sent in a format that can be viewed in real time, as it is being received. Instead, the data must be captured to a storage device and decoded for later use. Traditional satellite receivers and even many PC tuner cards are not capable of receiving these signals, and even if you have a card capable of receiving such signals, you also need special software to find such data streams and when one is found, to extract the data stream and save it.
The largest groups of end-users for Ku-band free-to-air signals were initially the ethnic-language communities, as often free ethnic-language programming would be sponsored by Multilingual American Communities and their broadcasters. Depending on language and origin of the individual signals, North American ethnic-language TV is a mix of pay-TV, free-to-air and DBS operations. Today, many American broadcasters send a multitude of programming channels in many languages, spanning many new channels, so they can get National support, which ultimately leads to carriage by cable systems, to additionally support the high costs of broadcasting signals in this way.
Nevertheless, free-to-air satellite TV is a viable addition to home video systems, not only for the reception of specialized content but also for use in locations where terrestrial [[ATSC]] over-the-air reception is incomplete and additional channels are desired.
==Asia/Oceania== ===Australia=== {{See also|Television in Australia|Freeview (Australia)}} [[Australia]] has five major free-to-air networks: [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC), [[Seven Network]], [[Nine Network]], [[Network Ten]], and [[Special Broadcasting Service]] (SBS). Traditionally each network had only a single channel in a geographic area, though with the advent of digital television each network now has [[SD video|SD]] multichannels [[7TWO]], [[7mate]], [[7flix]], [[9Go!]], [[9Gem]], [[9Life]], [[10 Boss]], [[10 Peach]], [[SBS Viceland]] and [[SBS Food]] respectively, and one [[High-definition television|HD]] networks simulcasting [[ABC HD (Australian TV channel)|ABC HD]], [[7HD]], [[9HD]], [[10 HD]] and [[SBS HD]] respectively. With the exception of SBS, each commercial broadcaster also has one SD [[datacasting]] channel: [[Your Money (TV channel)|Your Money]], [[TVSN]] and [[Spree TV]] respectively; SBS instead broadcasts [[National Indigenous Television|NITV]] free-to-air. The ABC is exempt from the policy limiting the number of multichannels, and currently runs three SD channels [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC]], [[ABC Comedy]], [[ABC ME]], [[ABC News (TV channel)|ABC News]], and a primary channel which is simulcast on both analogue and digital. ABC and SBS channels are available across Australia; outside the major capital cities, regional affiliates provide channels that are essentially identical to the metropolitan commercial channels. In addition, [[Community television in Australia|community television]] provides one channel in some major cities.
Australia's two main [[Public Broadcasting|government-owned TV channels]], the ABC and SBS, along with the digital-only multichannels ABC Comedy, ABC ME and SBS Viceland, are both available free-to-air on the [[Optus D1]] satellite. Viewers in remote parts of Australia could also access [[Seven Central]] and [[Imparja Television]], or [[WIN WA]] and [[GWN7]] in [[Western Australia]], through the DVB-S [[free-to-view]] [[Optus Aurora]] service, which was replaced in December 2013 with the DVB-S2 free-to-view Optus [[Viewer Access Satellite Television|VAST]] service.
Other satellite-only channels such as [[Expo Channel|Expo]], [[Press TV]] and [[Al Jazeera English]] are available free-to-air on various satellites.
===New Zealand=== {{Main article|List of free-to-air television stations in New Zealand}} New Zealand has a number of FTA broadcasters such as [[Television New Zealand]]'s [[TVNZ 1]] and [[TV2 (New Zealand)|TV2]], as well as [[MediaWorks New Zealand]]'s [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]] and [[C4 (TV channel)|FOUR]], [[Sky Network Television]]'s [[Prime Television New Zealand|Prime]] and the government subsidised the [[MÄori Television]] and [[Te Reo (TV channel)|Te Reo]] channels.
Four channels, TV One, TV2, TV3, FOUR are also broadcast timeshifted by +1 hour on Freeview and Sky platforms.
A broadcast of parliament and a number of local channels, such as [[Cue TV]] are also available. Local stations such as [[Canterbury Television|CTV]] and Face TV (previously Triangle TV) were free-to-air analogue PAL transmissions prior to CTV migrating to the free-to-air digital DVB-T service and Face TV's terrestrial free-to-air service shutoff from December 2013.
A digital terrestrial version of Freeview was launched in 2008, which, unlike the analogue and free-to-air satellite options, supports [[high-definition television|high-definition]] broadcasts for TV One, 2 and 3.
===Hong Kong=== In Hong Kong, the largest and most dominant television channel, [[Television Broadcasts Limited]], was the first free-to-air commercial television channel when it commenced broadcasting on 19 November 1967. It may also well be among the oldest and first station to broadcast over-the-air in East and Southeast Asia.
===South Korea=== In Korea, [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]] (the 2 main public broadcasters), [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS]] (privately owned, but available for free to viewers), and [[Educational Broadcasting System|EBS]] (including both [[TV]] and [[radio]]) are the free-to-air broadcasting stations. They dominate more than 80% of advertisement profits, according to the recent survey from the agency {{ambiguous|date=May 2017}}. Due to the recent government's {{which|date=May 2017}} decision, [[digital television]] service for all free-to-air networks would be scheduled before the year 2012, followed by the end of analog television broadcasting.
===India and South Asia=== {{See also|Television in India}} Around 600 FTA television channels and 180 Radio Channel are broadcast from ku-band and c-band transponders on the [[INSAT-4B]] and [[GSAT-15]] satellite covering India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Sri Lanka and parts of Afghanistan, China, and Myanmar. In India, the channels are marketed as [[DD Direct Plus]]/ [[DD Free Dish]] by [[Doordarshan]], India's national broadcaster and other Indian private broadcaster [[ABS Free Dish]] from the ABS2 satellite, one can receive free-to-air regional TV channels using small DTH antenna and freetoair set-top box.
===Middle East and North Africa=== {{empty section|date=May 2017}}
===Israel=== Up until 2012, Israel had several free-to-air channels, the major ones rating-wise: [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]], [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]], and [[Channel 1 (Israel)|Channel 1]]. The other ones were [[Israeli Educational Television|Channel 23]], [[Channel 33 (Israel)|Channel 33]], and [[Knesset Channel|Channel 99]].
== Europe == === Satellite === {{See also|List of free-to-air channels at 28Â°E}} European countries have a tradition of most television services being free to air. Germany, in particular, receives in excess of 100 digital satellite TV channels free to air. Approximately half of the television channels on [[SES Astra]]'s [[Astra 19.2Â°E|19.2Â° east]] and [[Astra 28.2Â°E|28.2Â° east]] satellite positions, and [[Eutelsat]]'s [[Hot Bird]] (13Â° east) are free-to-air.
A number of European channels which one might expect to be broadcast free-to-air - including many countries' national terrestrial broadcasters - do not do so ''via satellite'' for [[copyright]] reasons. (Rights to purchase programs for free-to-air broadcast, especially via satellite, are often higher in price than for encrypted broadcast.) However, these channels usually provide a scheme to offer free, but encrypted, viewing with [[free-to-view]] broadcasts. Certain programming on Italy's [[RAI]], and the majority of Dutch channels are covered by such schemes (although in the case of RAI some programming is transmitted without encryption where there are no copyright issues). In [[Austria]], the main national networks broadcast free-to-view via satellite; however, all regional and some smaller channels are transmitted free-to-air, and the national public broadcaster, [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]], offers a special free-to-air channel which airs selected programming without (i.e. those without copyright issues) via satellite all over Europe.
As Germany and Austria speak the same language and use the same satellite, Austrian viewers are able to receive about 120 free German-speaking channels from both countries.
In general, all [[satellite radio]] in Europe is free to air, but the more conventional broadcast systems in use mean that [[SiriusXM]] style in-car reception is not possible.
Cable and satellite distribution allow many more channels to carry sports, movies and specialist channels which are not broadcast as FTA. The viewing figures for these channels are generally much lower than the FTA channels.
=== Terrestrial === Various European countries broadcast a large number of channels via free-to-air [[terrestrial television|terrestrial]], generally as an analog [[PAL]]/[[SECAM]] transmission, digital [[DVB-T]]/[[DVB-T2|T2]] or a combination of the two.
==== France ==== {{main article|television in France}} In France, there are twenty six national television channels (MPEG-4 HD video) and 41 local television channels broadcast free-to-air via the TNT DVB-T service.
==== Germany ==== {{main article|television in Germany#terrestrial}} In Germany there are various free-to-air DVB-T services available, the number of which varies by region. [[Das Erste]], [[ZDF]], [[ZDFneo]], [[ZDFinfo]], [[3sat]], [[Arte]], [[KiKA]] and [[Phoenix (German TV station)|Phoenix]] are available throughout the country, in addition to at least one region-dependent channel which is provided by the regional [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] member. Additionally, ARD's [[EinsFestival]], [[EinsPlus]] and [[tagesschau24]] are variously available in some parts of the country, and various commercial channels are available in metropolitan areas.
==== Ireland ==== {{main article|Saorview}} In the Republic of Ireland, there are nine television channels and 11 radio channels broadcast free-to-air via the DVB-T Saorview service. Analog PAL versions of some of the channels were also broadcast until October 24, 2012, when all analogue television broadcasting was shut down.
==== Netherlands ==== {{main article|television in the Netherlands}} In the Netherlands, 3 national public television channels [[NPO 1]], [[NPO 2]] and [[NPO 3]], and 7 national public radio channels broadcast free-to-air via the DVB-T [[Digitenne]] service. The television and radio channels of the regional public broadcasters are also free-to-air via the DVB-T service.
==== United Kingdom ==== {{main article|Freeview (UK)|List of digital terrestrial television channels (UK)}} In the UK, around 220 free-to-air television channels and 25 free-to-air radio channels are available terrestrially via the Freeview DVB-T service. Seven HD channels are also broadcast via a public service broadcast multiplex and a commercial multiplex, both DVB-T2.
==== Denmark ==== In Denmark, nine channels are as of 2018 free-to-air<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digi-tv.dk/Indhold_og_tilbud/|title=Digi TV|website=digi-tv.dk}}</ref>, distributed via 18 main transmitter sites and 30 smaller, auxiliary transmitters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digi-tv.dk/Indhold_og_tilbud/frekvenser.asp|title=Digi TV|website=digi-tv.dk}}</ref>. The nine channels ([[DR1]], [[DR2]], [[DR3]], [[DR Ultra]], [[DR Ramasjang]], [[DR K]], [[Folketinget]], TV2 Regionerne, and sign language/local programme) come in two [[DVB-T2]] [[Multiplex_(television)|MUX]]es.

'''George MacClaren Wood III''' is an American journalist who has worked at [[Radio Sweden]] since 1975, He was born in [[Berkeley, California]] on August 10, 1949, and grew up in [[Piedmont, California]]. He has degrees from the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] and the [[University of California, Berkeley]], and participated in the university's Education Abroad Program to [[Lund University]] in Sweden, 1969-1970.
==Radio Sweden==
George Wood began as a freelance reporter at Radio Sweden in 1975.<ref>http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=567350</ref> Following the retirement of [[Arne Skoog]] in 1978 he told over the writing and presenting of the program [[Sweden Calling DXers]] and its successor MediaScan, until the latter was taken off the air in 2001. In 1994 MediaScan became the first radio program in Sweden and the second in Europe (the first in English) to have its audio posted on the Internet.
He was Radio Sweden's Webmaster since Swedish Radio's first website launched in 1995, while also serving as a journalist for the Radio Swedish English Service. His was one of the voices in the satirical sketches in the program the [[The Saturday Show (Radio Sweden)|Saturday Show]]. He retired from Radio Sweden in August, 2014.
==Egyptology==
After retirement George Wood enrolled in Egyptology courses at Uppsala University.
==Other activities==
George Wood was News Director of the university radio station [[KCSB-FM]] (at the University of California, Santa Barbara) in 1971-1973, and has also worked at [[KPFA]] in Berkeley, California, Earth News Service in San Francisco, and briefly as a freelancer for [[National Public Radio]]. Since the late 70's he has been the Stockholm stringer for [[CBS Radio]] News. He has written articles for a number of publications including "Satellite Times", "The [[World Radio TV Handbook]]", and the "[[New Age Journal]]".
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=567350 George Wood's page on the Radio Sweden website]

The '''Global Coalition Against Child Pneumonia''' exists to raise global awareness about the deadly toll of the number 1 killer of children - pneumonia. Every year 155 million children under 5 get sick and 1.6 million lose their lives to pneumonia, more than all child deaths combined from AIDS, malaria and measles. Almost all of these child deaths occur in developing countries with most concentrated in just seven - India, China, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Pakistan and Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rudan I, Boschi-Pinto C, Biloglav Z, Mulholland K, Campbell H |title=Epidemiology and etiology of childhood pneumonia |journal=Bull. World Health Organ. |volume=86 |issue=5 |pages=408â16 |date=May 2008 |pmid=18545744 |pmc=2647437 |url=http://www.scielosp.org/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0042-96862008000500019&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en |doi=10.2471/BLT.07.048769}}</ref>
Children die from pneumonia despite the existence of vaccines that can prevent the leading causes of pneumonia and cost-effective antibiotics that can treat children who are sick. The Global Coalition Against Child Pneumonia is working to save millions of lives through protecting children against pneumonia with proper nutrition through exclusive breastfeeding,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Roth DE, Caulfield LE, Ezzati M, Black RE |title=Acute lower respiratory infections in childhood: opportunities for reducing the global burden through nutritional interventions |journal=Bull. World Health Organ. |volume=86 |issue=5 |pages=356â64 |date=May 2008 |pmid=18545738 |pmc=2647440 |url=http://www.scielosp.org/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0042-96862008000500013&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en |doi=10.2471/blt.07.049114}}</ref> preventing pneumonia with new and existing vaccines, particularly [[Hib vaccine]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Watt JP, Wolfson LJ, O'Brien KL, etal |title=Burden of disease caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b in children younger than 5 years: global estimates |journal=Lancet |volume=374 |issue=9693 |pages=903â11 |date=September 2009 |pmid=19748399 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61203-4 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140-6736(09)61203-4}}</ref> and [[Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=O'Brien KL, Wolfson LJ, Watt JP, etal |title=Burden of disease caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae in children younger than 5 years: global estimates |journal=Lancet |volume=374 |issue=9693 |pages=893â902 |date=September 2009 |pmid=19748398 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61204-6 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140-6736(09)61204-6}}</ref> and treating pneumonia by training health workers to recognize symptoms of pneumonia and increasing access to appropriate antibiotic treatment.<ref name=unicef>{{cite book |author1=Matthew Hodge |author2=World Health Organization |author3=Tessa M. Wardlaw |author4=Emily White Johansson |title=Pneumonia: The Forgotten Killer of Children |publisher=United Nations Publications |location=New York, NY |year=2007 |isbn=92-806-4048-8 |url=http://www.unicef.org/publications/files/Pneumonia_The_Forgotten_Killer_of_Children.pdf}}</ref>
[http://www.who.int/child_adolescent_health/documents/9789241596336/en/ WHO] and UNICEF estimate that these interventions, combined with others, could save 1 million children's lives every year taking the world one big step closer to achieving [[Millennium Development Goals]].
==World Pneumonia Day== Pneumonia has been overshadowed as a priority on the global health agenda, and rarely receives coverage in the news media.<ref>{{cite news |author=Nicholas D. Kristof |title=Pssst. Pneumonia. Pass it on |url=http://kristof.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/28/pssst-pneumonia-pass-it-on/ |work=Blog: On the Ground |publisher=New York Times |date=March 28, 2009}}</ref> To combat this, the Global Coalition against Child Pneumonia is raising a collective voice to renew the global fight against pneumonia by holding [[World Pneumonia Day]] every year. It will provide an annual forum for the world to stand together and demand action in the fight against pneumonia. The first World Pneumonia Day was held on November 2, 2009 and in 2010 World Pneumonia Day falls on November 12. World Pneumonia Day will help bring this health crisis to the publicâs attention and will encourage policy makers and grass roots organizers alike to combat the disease.

{{Infobox organization | name = Hands Off the People of Iran | logo = | type = [[Interest group]] | founded_date = 2007 | location = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | key_people = [[Yassamine Mather]] (Chair)
[[Mark Fischer (activist)|Mark Fischer]] (Secretary)
[[MoshÃ© Machover]] | area_served = [[World]]wide | focus = [[Anti-war]], [[Peace]], [[Secularism]], [[Anti-clericalism]], [[Anti-imperialism]], [[Anti-capitalism]], [[Social equality]] | method = | revenue = | homepage = [http://www.hopoi.org www.hopoi.org] }} '''Hands Off the People of Iran''' (HOPI) is a political organisation in the [[United Kingdom]] founded in 2007, closely associated with the [[Communist Party of Great Britain (Provisional Central Committee)]]. It is opposed to [[Opposition to military action against Iran|Western military intervention in Iran]], as well as to the sitting Iranian government, and supports "internal" regime change. The three most prominent figures are Mike Macnair, the Israeli [[MoshÃ© Machover]] and [[Yassamine Mather]], an Iranian associated with the [[Workers Left Unity â Iran]]. It was denied affiliation with the [[Stop the War Coalition]] due to questions raised over its support for regime change. ==Formation== The initiative for Hands Off the People of Iran came from a number of Iranian exile organisations in 2005.[http://www.hopoi.org/whoweare.html Who we are] On March 16, 2006, [[Workers Left Unity - Iran]] wrote an open letter to the British [[anti-war movement]], calling for genuine solidarity with the Iranian people.[http://www.cpgb.org.uk/worker/616/iran%20workers%20unity.htm Open letter to the anti war movement] By 2007 HOPI was fully established, consisting predominantly of Iranian exiles who campaign for regime change in Iran but are against external military intervention, believing [[military occupation]] to be the worst condition under which liberation can be achieved. HOPI's founding conference was held in December 2007.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} At the Founding Conference, a National Steering Committee was established consisting of seventeen members from a range of different political organisations and political traditions. These include members of the [[Green Party of England and Wales]], [[British Labour Party#Labour Representation Committee|Labour Representation Committee]], [[Jewish Socialist Group]], [[Permanent Revolution Tendency|Permanent Revolution]], [[Centre for the Study of Socialist Theory and Movements]] at the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Communist Party of Great Britain (Provisional Central Committee)]], [[Workers Left Unity - Iran]], Revolutionary Workers of Iran, [[Anarchist Federation (Britain and Ireland)|Anarchist Federation]] (pc) and Womenâs Campaign Against All Misogynist Laws in Iran.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} An Irish branch of HOPI, chaired by Anne McShane, organised a protest outside the Iranian Embassy in Dublin in June 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0618/breaking22.htm|title=Iranians set for protest in Dublin|last=MAC CORMAIC|first=RUADHÃN|work=Irish Times|date=18 June 2009|accessdate=2009-07-07}}{{cite news|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/news/ireland/dublin-march-for-political-change-in-iran-416527.html|title=Dublin march for political change in Iran|date=27 June 2009|work=Ireland Online|accessdate=2009-07-07}}{{cite news|url=http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2009/jun/28/hundreds-attend-iran-support-rally/|title=Hundreds attend Iran support rally|date=28 June 2009|work=Sunday Tribune|accessdate=2009-07-07}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Expulsion from Stop the War Coalition== Shortly before [[STWC|Stop the War Coalition]]'s 2007 AGM, HOPI, alongside another organisation [[Communist Students (Autonomous)|Communist Students]], was denied affiliation with the Coalition.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/antiwar-activists-do-battle-over-intervention-in-iran-399450.html|title=Anti-war activists do battle over intervention in Iran|last=Taylor|first=Jerome|date=8 November 2007|work=The Independent|accessdate=2009-07-07}} ==Affiliates and Supporters== Prominent affiliates or supporters of HOPI include the [[Public and Commercial Services Union]];{{cite web|url=http://www.pcs.org.uk/en/news_and_events/record_of_decisions/2008/affiliations.cfm|title=Affiliations|year=2008|work=Public and Commercial Services Union|accessdate=2009-07-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127220307/http://pcs.org.uk/en/news_and_events/record_of_decisions/2008/affiliations.cfm|archivedate=2010-11-27|df=}} [[ASLEF]], the train drivers' union and [[Peter Tatchell]],.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2007/oct/26/iransantiarabracism|title=Iran's anti-Arab racism|last=Tatchell|first=Peter|date=26 October 2007|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-07-07}} ==See also== *[[Opposition to military action against Iran]] *[[Campaign Against Sanctions and Military Intervention in Iran]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hopoi.org Hopi's website] featuring news on the campaign *{{cite web|url=http://www.nearfm.ie/podcast/index.php?id=672|title=Hands off the People of Iran (Hopoi) calls for support for the Iranian people|last=FitzGerald|first=Michael|date=18 June 2009|work=[[NEAR
